message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle, which is responsible for flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints. None of the other options are responsible for this movement, and the intact flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints suggests that the injury is not affecting the flexor digitorum profundus muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints is intact suggests that the flexor digitorum profundus is not injured. The flexor carpi radialis and flexor carpi ulnaris muscles are responsible for wrist flexion and therefore not likely to cause weakness in the fingers. Therefore, the most likely muscle injured in this case is the flexor digitorum superficialis, which is responsible for flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle, which flexes the proximal interphalangeal joints. None of the other options primarily act on this joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has impaired flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints but not the distal interphalangeal joints suggests a selective injury to the Flexor digitorum superficialis muscle, which controls only the proximal interphalangeal joints. None of the other muscles listed have this selective control over the proximal interphalangeal joints.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptom of weakness in the fingers suggests damage to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle, which is responsible for flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints. The other muscles listed are responsible for flexion or pronation/supination of the forearm and wrist, not the fingers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests an injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle which allows flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint but not the distal interphalangeal joint. The flexor carpi radialis allows wrist flexion, the flexor carpi ulnaris allows wrist adduction, and the flexor digitorum profundus allows flexion of both the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. From the symptoms described, it is likely that there is an injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle, which flexes the middle phalanges of the fingers. The other options involve muscles that control wrist movement, not finger movement, so they are less likely to be affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially impaired flexion of proximal interphalangeal joints, suggest injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle. The other muscles mentioned do not have as significant of an impact on finger flexion at this location.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle, which is responsible for flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers. The other options are not responsible for this specific movement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The impairment of flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joints while flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints is intact suggests an injury to the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle. This muscle is responsible for flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joints, while the flexor digitorum profundus muscle is responsible for flexion at the distal interphalangeal joints. The flexor carpi radialis and flexor carpi ulnaris muscles are responsible for flexion at the wrist joint, not the finger joints.
